title: American_Top_40_1974_January_19th
description:
"These are the most popular songs from Maine to Hawaii, from Alaska to Florida. I'm Casey Kasem and the countdown doesn't stop until we get to number one."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this countdown:

A listener wants to know, "What is the longest running number one record in chart history?" Casey says the song came out in 1950, was number one for 13 consecutive weeks, and then gives the details.

There is a hit whose proceeds go to the American Red Cross. It is one of two spoken-word recordings in the countdown. The other is "Sister Mary Elephant" (at number 24) by Cheech & Chong.

A listener asks, "Has it ever happened that a group became recording stars, broke up, then got back together and made it to number one on the chart?" Casey says only once, three English brothers who never did make it to number one the first time they were together.

There is a man in this countdown who became a millionaire as a result of the last minute decision to make him the drummer.

Casey counts down to a song by Brownsville Station ("Smokin' In The Boys Room" at number 3), and then tells what station in Brownsville broadcasts his countdown!
